Title: Comfort and Joy

reviewText: I have seen this compared to Nic Cage's "family man" but I think this is much better. Jane is a single successful woman, who isn't as much unhappy with her life, she just doesn't know how empty it is. On Christmas eve she gets in a car accident and wakes up to her husband asking if she is ok. Except she has no idea who this man is, and has no memory of her "kids." Freaked out, she goes about trying to get back to her life, but her apartment has someone else in it, her on and off boyfriend tells her he hasn't seen her in 10 years, and even her drivers license says she is married. With no place else to go she goes back to her *husband* and kids and does her best to adjust to her life. Ultimately she likes this life better than her single one.A couple of things that sets this apart from "family man". Jane is likable. Jane's husband, Sam, truly seems to love her and Jane's children both can act and make it appear that they love Jane also. Jane's new life comes with sacrifices but they are not so bad as that audience can't see the appeal.In the end she does got back to single life, but of course, gets to meet Sam and live the life she only previewed before. Very good flick, well acted and well plotted.
Title: Comfort and Joy

reviewText: The story told here is much like the story from 'It's a Wonderful Life."  It also bears a strong resemblance to the Nicholas Cage vehicle "The Family Man."  An upwardly mobile, single young woman has an accident on Christmas Eve and wakes up married with children.  I will not go into great detail here, but she finds out what she's really been missing in her life and it changes her values and goals in life. If you like the two films I mentioned earlier, then I am sure you will enjoy this movie.  I gave it four stars because all of the actors do a good job, but Paul Dooley, who plays the young woman's father is a standout and he really makes the film worth watching.  This is a fun film for the entire family.
Title: Comfort and Joy

reviewText: A Lifetime Original Movie, this is a very similar film to Nicholas Cage's "Family Man." Nancy McKeon plays a very sucessful, yet emotionally unsatisfied, corporate executive. She is the epitome of the "21st century woman"- independent, powerful, beautiful apartment, expensive car- but is she really happy? Her empty relationship with a co-worker and dysfunctional family make it especially difficult to just plow through the holiday season without taking stock of what her life has become. Despite her outward success, the unspoken question in her mind is " How did I get here?"The idea of a different life is put to the test when she has an accident and wakes up in an alternate reality as a wife, mother and pillar of her community. She also sees how her different life choices affect those around her. The alternate life does not come without its compromises (no expensive car or clothes in this version of life), but do the pros outweigh the cons? Are the benefits  of this "new" life enough to make her stay? Are the experiences in the alternate life fulfilling enough to make her want to jump ship and set her sights for a new shore?I won't answer that question. You'll have to see how it turns out for yourself.It is a great movie for anyone who has ever wondered "what if" or who has thought that "the grass is always greener on the other side." It is a story about finding your life's balance and knowing that, whatever you choose, does not come without its sacrifices.  Those sacrifices, however, if it's the right choice for you, are a small price to pay for true happiness and living your best life.
Title: Comfort and Joy

reviewText: At the heart of this what-if movie is the decision to run through life alone, defining success as a high level of achievement in the workplace.  We get to watch the definition change.  The writing is excellent, bringing in humor that is well-played by the stunning cast.  The message delivered reflects great direction and basic chemistry between the leads.  Truly just an enjoyable experience.  I bought several to give as gifts because I got it a year ago and still thought about this "family" as a unit, sitting around the table and later trying to work out various unexpected details, and laughed at each recollection.  I wanted my friends to be able to do the same.  Very nice DVD to keep and re-enjoy.
Title: Comfort and Joy

reviewText: Nancy McKeun plays her role very well...a Christmas fantasy that shows a successfull business woman who thinks she has it all, that perhaps she has missed out on better life which her car crashes on the way to a Christmas party at her boss's house and she wakes up from the accident in her car, rescued by her husband...and two kids.  For a little while she lives the role of this married lady who has a great husband and two wonderful kids...she goes into this life kicking and screaming insisting that she isn't married; but later realizes that perhaps this life is better and more fulfilling than the one she had chasing money.  Again, this movie teaches us the lesson that Christmas isn't about material wealth but a different kind of wealth that cannot be bought by money!  This is great family fare and I would highly recommend it!
Title: Comfort and Joy

reviewText: After seeing this movie, I thought immediately to Charles Dickens' Ghost of Christmas Future in "The Christmas Carol." That's essentially whatComfort and Joyis about. The main character, Jane, relives a portion of her future, which she finds more pleasant than her current life. Like the Ghost of Christmas Future, the vision allows Jane to see what was wrong with the "old Jane" and how to life life in accord with the Christmas spirit.I knocked this movie down a star because, while I love the concept, it does look like a made-for-TV movie. The characters are decent, but sometimes a little to wholesome (particularly Sam, Jane's future husband). There really is never any climax to the movie, and it ends rather abruptly. And the cuts to commercials are a bit too obvious. Some of this is simply the editing job as Lifetime transferred the movie from TV to DVD. Still, it just feels like it reached less than its potential.
summary: A friendlier version of the Ghost of Christmas Future
Title: Comfort and Joy

(A recent fee for a cat carrier was a high percentage of the original price.) Although I used the online form, I never received a reply to my query. Great customer service. Returns are a pain in the neck at amazon: too short a return time and too high a return fee. In the future I'm going to order more prudently.
Title: Comfort and Joy

reviewText: COMFORT & JOY just doesn't do it for me as a movie title; it's so blah. Thankfully, the movie itself rises above its title. If, like me, you'd wondered what in heck happened to that tough, street-savvy tomboy from THE FACTS OF LIFE, well, Nancy McKeon, a.k.a. Jo Polniaczek, has been all this time churning out made-for-television movies.Her 2003 Lifetime movie, COMFORT & JOY, is an upside-down version of IT'S A WONDERFUL LIFE. It's a gender-reversed riff onThe Family Man (Widescreen Collector's Edition)(2000). It predatesA Family Thanksgiving(2010), Daphne Zuniga's similarly-themed television film. These movies play on our proclivity to indulge in the "What if?" game. Should I place a Mild Plot Spoilers alert here? (I think I just did.) Jane Berry (Nancy McKeon), workaholic vice-president of a Connecticut advertising firm, sees Christmas Eve as just another work day. She's conned herself into believing her life is aces and oh-so-fulfilling. Never mind that her relationship with her glib boyfriend is sunk in inertia. ("How is Peter Pan?" Jane's dad wryly enquires of her smug significant other.)On this Christmas Eve, see Jane Berry battle inclement weather while enroute to some festive work function. See her lose control of the wheel and her Jaguar careen into a street post. Jane wakes up to a flipped scenario. She's suddenly a housewife in the 'burbs with two kids and a stranger for a husband. So the question is, is this a time travel fantasy or a severely prolonged case of amnesia?It's not like Jane's old life never existed. It's just that she seems to have lost the past ten years. She marvels and is alarmed at the drastic shifts. This Jane she inhabits now is perceived as a pillar of the community, is content to be a stay-at-home mom, has relinquished the ambitions of a driven career woman, has long ago traded her Jag for an unsleek station wagon. I guess, somewhen in that interim, she took to heart another of her dad's sayings: "Make more or desire less."See Jane try to come to grips. Witness her periodic freak-outs and her children's bombarding her with questions like "Mom, are you going nuts?" and "What's it like to go nuts?" and "Mom, are you still nuts?" The one familiar thing is that her parents still exist in a nettled state of dysfunction. Is that Dixie Carter playing Jane's insufferably obnoxious - her fans would call her performance "sassy" - mom? Yes, it is.Somewhere along the way, Jane Berry - er, Jane Keller - does get a grip. She begins to enjoy her cute kids and appreciate her kind husband Sam (Steven Eckholdt). It's a plot development that surely won't stun any viewer. The only conundrum to keep you and me on tenterhooks is how will things resolve? And, oh yeah, is it time travel after all? Or a case of amnesia? COMFORT & JOY (Uggh, that title again) is a solid holiday movie, and Nancy McKeon is as watchable as ever. I'm calling it an above average 3.5 out of 5 stars. In today's ubiquitous social media, I only wish there were more water cooler talk whenever Nancy McKeon makes a movie. I can't be typing "imdb" all the time, mostly because I've worn out the "i" tab on my keyboard. Oh, well, you take the good, you take the bad...
summary: So, Jane, make more or desire less?
Title: Comfort and Joy

reviewText: A sweet,simple story reminiscent in many ways of It's A Wonderful Life.  An overworked executive finds love on a cold, snowy night in the most unimaginable of ways.  I will not provide a spoiler except to say this movie touts traditional values of charity, kindness, etc... Above all, it reflects the value of Godly love,  familial love, and romantic love!

reviewText: This movie is definitely at the top of my list when it comes to Christmas viewing. It's cute, funny, has a great message and I love the idea of being transported into "alternate life" with a little bit of Christmas magic. I also like this one because it doesn't fall into that dreadful category of cheesy, overdone Holiday movies. The actors all do a a good job of making the premise as believable as possible and the movie flows very well.
Title: Comfort and Joy

reviewText: Comfort and Joy is one of those films that warms the heart any time of year. Has your life every been satisfying on one level, yet you wonder... What if there was something more? Nancy McKeaon turns in a wonderful performance as a modern career woman in just such a quandary, and is forced to come to terms with it after an accident causes her to wake up in an alternate reality that she can't wait to escape. Of course, after time, she realizes that the trade-off she is making is worth so much more than whatever she could be leaving behind. After all, it's all about the choices we make, any time of year.
summary: What if you could have a new life?
Title: Comfort and Joy

reviewText: I expected this one to be a lot of fun.  I liked the actors, but the plot is just too contrived, and McKeon is frankly, a bit hostile and unlikeable.  I think they could have done a lot more with this than they did. Better modern picks are A Boyfriend for Christmas, The Christmas Card, even The Snowglobe, which is silly but fun. Oldies but goodies like Shop Around the Corner, It's a Wonderful Life, A Christmas Carol and even all of the children's classics are fun, or just tune into whatever Lifetime or Hallmark are playing that year to find the best new ones.  This year, I enjoyed watching Christmas Mail.
summary: I'm donating this one to the library
Title: Comfort and Joy

reviewText: Lots of people think that this is a lesser version of the Nicholas Cage Movie Family Man, but I think it is better.  In Family Man, he missed the boat.  The events that took place there had already happened.  The children he met were born in the past.  Whatever happens with him after the end of the movie, it won't be the same as the glimpse he received.  On the other hand, this movie shows her the FUTURE.  She meets her husband before they have their wonderful children.  Her future of hope is left as a happy ending in this film instead of a sea of regret in Family Man.  I love this movie and watch it every year.

reviewText: This movie starring Nancy McKeon is just great.  It's not your typical Christmas movie, but takes you into a time warp where she falls in love.  So, if you're into Christmas Chick Flicks, this one is for you.  Dixie Carter makes the best mother-in-law and Steven Eckholdt the greatest dad/husband.  McKeon, a successful advertising executive, has a car accident in front of Eckholdt's house.  She wakes up to 10 years later when she's married to him and has turned into a giving, sharing, philanthropist who has given up her worldy goods to help others -- only she doesn't remember any of it.It has some really funny spots and a great ending.
Title: Comfort and Joy

reviewText: I think at one time or another we have all had a dream (or nightmare), about suddenly finding ourselves in a world where either everyone we know and love suddenly dont recognise us or that complete strangers know and love us but we have absolutely no recollection of who they are. This theme was probably handled most famously in the immortal "It's a Wonderful Life", where James Stewart's character of George Bailey had a unique opportunity to see what life would have been like for others if he had never lived. Lifetime's Christmas television movie "Comfort and Joy", explores a similiar theme where the main character Jane, a driven materialistic career woman played by Nancy McKeon, after enduring a car accident on Christmas Eve suddenly finds herself propelled 10 years into the future into a whole life she does not recognise and doesn't really at first want. All the confusion, anguish, and soul searching by Jane makes for both amusing and touching viewing and Nancy McKeon does wonderful work as the young women suddenly discovering she has a husband and two children and a whole new lifestyle she never imagined was possible or desirable. Ably supported by one of my favourite television actors in the talented Steven Eckholdt as Jane's equally confused husband Sam, this pair of telelvision veterans work beautifully together depicting a couple having to literally start from scratch again in building their relationship as the Christmas festivities fast approach.
summary: Charming Christmas Tale With Supernatural Elements
Title: Comfort and Joy

reviewText: I love movies that offer the "what if" scenario.  Nancy McKeon is down to earth and very likeable in her lead role.  As the film begins, McKeon is presented as a very successful career woman, who lives alone.  On her way home from the office, on Christmas eve, her car hits a patch of black ice and she swerves out of control, bumping her head in the process.  What follows is akin to the plot in "The Family Man" (although not as well done).  The man that rushes to her aid, claims to be her husband.  He ushers her into the house across the street, despite her arguments, where two solicitous children begin calling her "mom."  McKeon embarks on a journey to discover what is real and what is fantasy.  It was a cute show.
Title: Comfort and Joy

reviewText: I love this movie.  I watched it several times on TV and finally bought it.  It's the perfect movie to watch for the holidays.  It teaches us that money, etc. aren't what's important in life.  The character that Nancy McKeon plays learns this by seeing into her potential future over the holidays.  It's similar to Nicholas Cage's "Family Man", "Mr. Destiny", Jennifer Love Hewitt's "If Only", and other movies that allow the characters to see the "what if" scenarios of how their life may turn out or may have turned out if they would have taken a different path in life.
Title: Comfort and Joy

reviewText: This movie was fun to watch. It's a nice and easy one to view while decorating for the holidays or just relaxing in your PJ's with a steaming cup of tea.
Title: Comfort and Joy
